chapter: Diagnosis of Pregnancy and Antenatal Care

questions.question: Question 1: What is the duration of the 4th trimester in pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
The duration of the fourth trimester is 12 weeks postpartum. The concept of fourth trimester was introduced to address common concerns raised by women in 
puerperium such as post-partum pain, breastfeeding related problems, stress and postpartum 
depression, and lack of awareness of newborn care. The components of postpartum care for the 
4th trimester include: • Dedicated care team • Lactation support • Infant feeding plan • Reproductive life plan 133 
Sold by @itachibot • Contraception • Addressing complications of pregnancy • Assessment of cardiovascular risk • Mental health assessment • Chronic health conditions ACOG recommendation for postpartum visits: • Initial visit: 3 weeks postpartum • Final visit: 12 weeks postpartum Government of India recommendation for postpartum visits. • First visit: 1st day after delivery • Second visit: 3rd day after delivery • Third visit: 7th day after delivery • Fourth visit: 6 weeks after delivery
questions.chapter_heading: Diagnosis of Pregnancy and Antenatal Care

questions.question: Question 2: What is the ideal number of antenatal visits?
questions.explanation:
The ideal number of antenatal visits is 12-14. The antenatal visits should ideally be: monthly once up to 28 weeks, once in two weeks between 
28-36 weeks, and once weekly visits from 36 weeks onwards. This translates to a total of 12-15 visits. The WHO increased the minimum number of antenatal visits from 4 to 8 visits to reduce 
perinatal mortality. In the Indian scenario, the earlier minimum of 4 visits were implemented as follows: • 1st visit: within 12 weeks (preferably as soon as pregnancy is suspected) • 2nd visit: between 14-26 weeks • 3rd visit: between 28-34 weeks • 4th visit: between 36 weeks and term A booked case is one that has at least 3 antenatal visits with two visits in the third trimester.
questions.chapter_heading: Diagnosis of Pregnancy and Antenatal Care

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following statements is not true about parity?

options.a: Parity refers to the number of previous pregnancies reaching viability
options.b: If a woman has twins, the parity remains one
options.c: If a woman has a stillborn child, her parity decreases
options.d: Multipara is a woman who has completed 2 or more pregnancies past the period of viability

questions.explanation:
If a female has stillbirth, her parity does not decrease. Parity is determined by the number of previous pregnancies reaching a period of viability, which 
is 28 weeks in India. 134 
Sold by @itachibot Multifetal pregnancies, such as twins or triplets, count as one for the purpose of this notation. The 
current pregnancy is not included in this count. Multipara refers to a woman who has completed two or more pregnancies past the period of 
viability. When the pregnancy is preceded by five or more previous viable pregnancies, the woman 
is called a grand multipara. Note: Gravida indicates the number of times the mother has been pregnant, regardless of whether 
these pregnancies were carried to term. The current pregnancy is included in this count.
questions.chapter_heading: Diagnosis of Pregnancy and Antenatal Care

questions.question:
Question 4: A 30-year-old woman came to the OPD with a twin pregnancy at 10 weeks of gestation. She 
has a 3-year-old female child who was born at term and had 2 first trimester abortions 
previously. Which of the following is the correct representation of her obstetric score.
questions.explanation:
The obstetric score is G4 P1 A2 L1. The obstetric score is used to summarise the past obstetric history as follows: • G - Gravidity, denoting the total number of pregnancies, including the present one • P - Parity, denoting the total number of pregnancies crossing the period of viability • This includes both live births and stillbirths • The current pregnancy is not included • A - Abortus or the number of pregnancies that were lost for any reason, including induced 
abortions or miscarriages. • L - Living children Multifetal pregnancies count as one for both gravida and para. A pregnant woman who delivers 
twins will be expressed as primipara. The GTPAL system includes the following: • Gravida • Term (>37 weeks) • Preterm (20w - 36w 6d) • Abortions (<20 weeks) • Number of living children Note: The period of viability is when the fetus is capable of independent existence. The WHO 
defines it to be 24 weeks while the Indian definition is 28 weeks.
questions.chapter_heading: Diagnosis of Pregnancy and Antenatal Care

questions.question:
Question 5: A lady who is 38 weeks pregnant comes to the OPD for a routine checkup. She has a history 
of normal twin delivery at term 4 years ago. What is her gravida and para score?
questions.explanation:
The woman has had two pregnancies in total - the previous twin pregnancy and the current 
pregnancy, hence the gravida score is 2. The first pregnancy resulted in delivery at term (crossed 
viable period), hence her para score is 1 (parity doesn't include current pregnancy). Hence, her 
obstetric score would be G2P1 (Gravida - 2, Para - 1). 135 
Sold by @itachibot Multifetal pregnancies count as one for both gravida and para. A pregnant woman who delivers 
twins for the first time is expressed as primipara. The obstetric score is used to summarise the past obstetric history as follows: • G - Gravidity, denoting the total number of pregnancies, including the present one • P - Parity, denoting the total number of pregnancies crossing the period of viability. This 
includes both live births and stillbirths. The current pregnancy is not included. • A - Abortion is the termination of pregnancy, either spontaneous or induced, before fetal 
viability. • L - Living children. The GTPAL system includes the following: • Gravida • Term (>37 weeks) • Preterm (20w - 36w 6d) • Abortions (<20 weeks) • Number of living children Note: The period of viability is when the fetus is capable of independent existence. The WHO 
defines it to be 24 weeks while the Indian definition is 28 weeks.
questions.chapter_heading: Diagnosis of Pregnancy and Antenatal Care

questions.question:
Question 6: A woman whose obstetric score is G2 P1 L1 had an LMP of Jan 9th 2017. Calculate the EDD 
according to Naegele’s rule.
questions.explanation:
As per Naegele’s rule, the EDD (expected date of delivery) of this woman is October 16, 2017. Naegele’s rule states that EDD is obtained by adding 7 days and subtracting 3 months from the 
LMP (the 1st day of the last menstrual period). Another method is adding 9 months and 7 
days to LMP. Less than 5% of births follow Naegele's rule. It is based on a 28-day regular cycle. If the cycle is shorter/longer than 28 days, corrected EDD is 
calculated as follows: • For a 35-day cycle, add another 7 (35-28=7) days to the calculated EDD to get the corrected 
EDD. • For a 25-day cycle, subtract 3 (28-25=3) days from the calculated EDD to get the corrected EDD. Naegele’s rule cannot be followed in IVF pregnancies. Considering the human embryo takes 266 
days to develop, EDD is calculated in IVF pregnancies by the following method: • Same day as fertilization (day 0): EDD = date of transfer + 266 days • 3 days after fertilization (day 3): EDD = date of transfer + 263 days • 5 days after fertilization (day 5): EDD = date of transfer + 261 days
questions.chapter_heading: Diagnosis of Pregnancy and Antenatal Care

questions.question:
Question 7: The recommended calorie intake for a pregnant woman in the second trimester, who is a 
sedentary worker would increase by  
.
questions.explanation:
136 
Sold by @itachibot The recommended calorie intake for a pregnant woman in the second trimester would increase by 
~ 350 kcal/day.
questions.chapter_heading: Diagnosis of Pregnancy and Antenatal Care

questions.question:
Question 8: A pregnant lady of 49 kg is in her first trimester. What are her additional calorie 
requirements in this trimester? 128 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The pregnant lady can continue the same diet since there are no additional calorie requirements 
in the first trimester. Pregnancy requires an additional 80,000 kcal, mostly during the last 20 weeks. To meet this 
demand, a caloric increase of 100 to 300 kcal/d is recommended during pregnancy. This greater 
intake, however, should not be divided equally during the course of pregnancy. The Institute of 
Medicine (2006) recommends adding 0, 340, and 452 kcal/d to the estimated nonpregnant energy 
requirements in the first, second, and third trimesters respectively. Whenever caloric intake is inadequate, protein is metabolized rather than being spared for its vital 
role in fetal growth and development.
questions.chapter_heading: Diagnosis of Pregnancy and Antenatal Care

questions.question:
Question 9: A 22-year-old pregnant woman at 13 weeks of gestation informs you about accidental 
exposure to radiation from a chest X-ray at 7 weeks of gestation. What should be the next step 
advised to her?
questions.explanation:
In the given clinical case, the patient should be advised to continue the pregnancy. The radiation dose to the fetus during the declared term of pregnancy should be less than 1 
mSv. In chest X-ray PA view, the absorbed dose of radiation by the fetus is less than 0.1 mSv. 
Hence, pregnancy can be continued. An X-ray has a very limited role in obstetric imaging. There are very few indications where an 
X-ray will be useful: • Fetal: congenital malformation of the fetus and neonates, skeletal malformations, birth injuries 
like fractures or dislocations. • Maternal: Patients having cardiopulmonary disease may require an X-ray chest during 
pregnancy and that should be done beyond 12 weeks. Radiation can cause fetal morbidity (FGR, genetic mutations, neurologic abnormalities, mental 
retardation, childhood leukemia) and mortality. The risks are high with radiation after the first 2 
weeks postconception and within the first trimester (period of organogenesis). Radiation during pregnancy can damage the early phase of the embryo but the risk can be 
minimized by using the ‘10-day rule’. This rule states that no woman should be exposed to an 
X-ray for a nonurgent indication outside 10 days from her last period during the reproductive 
period unless the pregnancy is excluded. The given table below shows the absorbed radiation by the fetus in different diagnostic radiation 
procedures: 1 cGy = 10 mSv 137 
Sold by @itachibot Procedure 
Dose (c 
Gy) 0.1-0.3 Abdominal X-ra 
y Pelvic X-ray 
0.5-1.1 Chest X-ray 
<0.001 Abdominal CT 
0.4-0.8 Chest CT 
0.002-0. 
02 2.5-3.5 Abdominopelvic CT Ventilation scan 
0.007-0. 
05 PET scan 
1-1.5
questions.chapter_heading: Diagnosis of Pregnancy and Antenatal Care

questions.question:
Question 10: You notice an obstetrics resident performing the following manoeuvres on a 37-week 
primigravida. Choose the correctly matched set.
questions.explanation:
Fetal pole, lie, presenting part, engagement, and attitude of fetal head are assessed by Leopold's 
manoeuvres: • Fundal grip (first Leopold): • Assesses the uterine fundus. • Helps in identification of fetal lie and determination of fetal pole at the fundus. • The breech gives the sensation of a large, irregular mass. • The head feels hard and round and is more mobile. • Lateral grip (second Leopold): • Assesses the fetal orientation. • The palms are placed on either side of the maternal abdomen, and gentle but deep pressure is 
exerted. • The back is felt on one side as a hard, resistant structure. • The fetal extremities are felt on the other side as numerous small, irregular, mobile parts are 
felt. • Fetal orientation can be determined by noting whether the back is directed anteriorly, 
transversely, or posteriorly. • The position of the anterior shoulder is mainly assessed by this grip. • Pawlik's grip / 1st pelvic grip (third Leopold): • Assesses the presenting part in respect to the true pelvis. • The thumb and fingers of one hand grasp the lower portion of the maternal abdomen just above 
the symphysis pubis. 138 
Sold by @itachibot • If the presenting part is not engaged, a movable mass will be felt, usually the head. • Deep pelvic grip / 2nd pelvic grip (fourth Leopold): • Assesses the engagement, attitude of the fetal head and determine the degree of descent. • The examiner faces the mother's feet, and the fingertips of both hands are positioned on either 
side of the presenting part. • They exert inward pressure and then slide along the axis of the pelvic inlet. • If the head has already descended into the pelvis, the anterior shoulder or the space created by 
the neck may be differentiated readily from the head. • It is the only grip performed facing the feet.
questions.chapter_heading: Diagnosis of Pregnancy and Antenatal Care

questions.question:
Question 11: A dusky hue of the vestibule and anterior vaginal wall visible at about 8 weeks of pregnancy is 
called  
.
questions.explanation:
A dusky hue of the vestibule and anterior vaginal wall visible at about 8th week of pregnancy is 
called Chadwick’s sign or Jacquemier’s sign. The discoloration is due to local vascular congestion.
questions.chapter_heading: Diagnosis of Pregnancy and Antenatal Care

questions.question:
Question 12: A primigravida comes for a routine ANC visit at 22 weeks of gestation. Which of the following 
signs would you not expect?
questions.explanation:
Lightening is felt in the 3rd trimester (38th week) in a primigravida. It is a sense of relief from the 
pressure symptoms due to engagement of the presenting part. The 2nd trimester of pregnancy is characterised by the following: Sign

questions.chapter_heading: Diagnosis of Pregnancy and Antenatal Care

questions.question: Question 13: Which of the following statements is not true regarding uterine souffle?

options.a: It is a soft blowing systolic murmur heard on the sides of pregnant uterus
options.b: The sound is synchronous with the maternal pulse
options.c: It is due to increased blood flow through the umbilical arteries
options.d: It can also be heard in a large fibroid

questions.explanation:
Uterine souffle is due to an increase in blood flow through the dilated uterine vessels, not 
umbilical vessels. It is a soft blowing systolic murmur heard low down at the sides of the uterus, better heard on the 
left side. Uterine Souffle 
Fetal/Funic Souffle Soft, blowing sound 
Sharp, whistling sound Synchronous withfetal pulse. Synchronous withmaternal p 
ulse Caused by the passage of blo 
od through dilateduterine ves 
sels Caused by the rush of blood t 
hrough theumbilical arteries It can also be heard in a large When present it isdiagnostic 
of pregnancy uterine fibroid
questions.chapter_heading: Diagnosis of Pregnancy and Antenatal Care

questions.question:
Question 14: A 32-year-old woman nearing her due date was admitted following regular contractions. You 
note that the head is at +1 station. Where is the exact position of the head?

options.d: High up in the false pelvis

questions.explanation:
+1 station of the fetal head refers to it being just below the ischial spine. The station of the head is expressed in relation to ischial spines as they are the most prominent 
bony projections felt on internal examination. The level of ischial spines is halfway between the 
pelvic inlet and outlet. This level is known as station zero (0). 140 
Sold by @itachibot The station is stated in minus figures if it is above the spines (–1 cm, –2 cm, –3 cm, –4 cm and –5 
cm) and in plus figures if it is below the spines (+1 cm, +2 cm, +3 cm, +4 cm and +5 cm).
questions.chapter_heading: Diagnosis of Pregnancy and Antenatal Care

questions.question:
Question 15: While examining a pregnant woman, you measure her fundal height to be 32 cm and the 
station of the fetal head is at -2. What could be the probable weight of the fetus?
questions.explanation:
The fetal weight in the above case is 3.1Kg. In the above case, fetal weight can be estimated using Johnson's formula. Height of uterus is 
32cm, the station is –2 implying the head is above the ischial spines. Therefore, it is calculated as 
follows: [32-12] x 155 = 3100 grams = 3.1Kg Estimation of fetal weight: • Johnson’s formula: This is only applicable in vertex presentation. • If station of head is below the level of the ischial spine: [Height of uterus above pubic symphysis 
(in cm)-11] x 155 in grams • If station of head is above the level of the ischial spine: [Height of uterus above pubic symphysis 
(in cm)-12] x 155 in grams • Sonography: Fetal weight has been estimated by combining a number of biometric data, e.g. 
biparietal diameter (BPD), head circumference (HC), abdominal circumference (AC) and femur 
length (FL), using the following formulae: • Shepard’s formula • Hadlock’s formula. 141 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Diagnosis of Pregnancy and Antenatal Care

questions.question:
Question 16: All of the following are components of Manning score except  
.
questions.explanation:
The oxytocin challenge test is not a component of Manning score. Earlier, oxytocin challenge test/contraction stress test was done after a non-reactive NST to 
confirm the diagnosis of hypoxia. However, it is associated with the risk of initiating labor and is 
hence not done. Biophysical profile (BPP)/Manning score components: (Mnemonic: BATMaN) • Breathing movements of the fetus • Amniotic fluid voulme • Tone of fetus • Movements of fetus • Non-stress Test (NST) Normal score: 8-10; Abnormal: <5 Modified Biophysical score: • VAST (Vibroacoustic stimulation test)/NST • Amniotic fluid index A score <4 indicates the need for urgent delivery.
questions.chapter_heading: Diagnosis of Pregnancy and Antenatal Care

questions.question:
Question 17: A 28-year-old G2P1 woman presents to the antenatal clinic at 24 weeks for a routine 
check-up. USG shows a normal for gestational age fetus in frank breech position, with no 
other abnormalities. What is the next best step in ■management?
questions.explanation:
75gm oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) is the most appropriate next step of management. The 
screening strategy for detecting gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) recommends performing 
blood glucose testing at 24-28 weeks in case of average risk. 142 
Sold by @itachibot Breech presentation at 24 weeks is not a cause for concern because it can spontaneously rotate 
and becomes cephalic at term. Hence, external cephalic version (ECV) and immediate caesarean 
section are not indicated at this time.
questions.chapter_heading: Diagnosis of Pregnancy and Antenatal Care

questions.question: Question 18: Which of the following vaccines is absolutely contraindicated in pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
MMR is absolutely contraindicated in pregnancy. Killed vaccines are safe in pregnancy while live vaccines (MMR, BCG, varicella) are 
contraindicated in pregnancy. Even though yellow fever vaccine is a live vaccine, it is recommended in endemic areas or during 
outbreaks. Pregnant women and nursing mothers should be counselled on the potential benefits 
and risks of vaccination.
questions.chapter_heading: Diagnosis of Pregnancy and Antenatal Care

questions.question:
Question 19: A newly married couple planning for pregnancy has come to your clinic for preconception 
counselling. Which of the following drugs will you prescribe to the patient to decrease the 
chances of having neural tube defects in the baby?
questions.explanation:
Preconceptional intake of vitamin B9 (folic acid) results in decreased incidence of neural tube 
defects like spina bifida, encephalocele, and anencephaly. All women of reproductive age should be given 400 µg of folic acid daily. Women, who had fetal 
neural tube defects in the previous pregnancy, should be given 4 mg of folic acid daily beginning 1 
month before conception to about 12 weeks of pregnancy.
questions.chapter_heading: Diagnosis of Pregnancy and Antenatal Care

questions.question: Question 20: Which of the following conditions would not cause raised beta-hCG levels in pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
Beta-hCG levels are reduced in the case of spontaneous abortion. Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) is detectable in the plasma of pregnant women as early as 
7-8 days after conception by radioimmunoassay. It doubles every 2 days and reaches a maximum 
level at 9 weeks. Thereafter, it declines to reach the lower level at 20 weeks and disappears from 
circulation 2 weeks postpartum. Increased levels of beta-hCG are found in: • Multiple preganancies • Rh isoimmunization • Down's syndrome • Choriocarcinoma • Hydatidiform mole Decreased levels of beta-hCG are found in: • Ectopic pregnancies • Impending spontaneous abortion 143 
Sold by @itachibot • Missed abortion • Edward syndrome.
questions.chapter_heading: Diagnosis of Pregnancy and Antenatal Care

questions.question: Question 21: Which of the following is not considered as a factor for a high-risk pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
Previous manual removal of the placenta does not indicate a high-risk pregnancy. The high-risk pregnancies according to the Pregnancy Risk Assessment Monitoring System by the
